discussion.content: Not on CCNA exam any more.

questions.question_text: What does the frame-relay interface-dlci command configure?
questions.answer_description:
Frame Relay for ICND Exam -
http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=100603&seqNum=3
To assign a data-link connection identifier (DLCI) to a specified Frame Relay subinterface on the router or access server, or to assign a specific permanent virtual circuit (PVC) to a DLCI, or to apply a virtual template configuration for a PPP session, use the frame-relay interface-dlci interface configuration command.
Example 4-23 Example of frame-relay interface-dlci Command and the Output of show frame-relay map
R4(config)#interface s1/2.403 point-to-point
R4(config-subif)#frame-relay interface-dlci ?
<16-1007> Define a switched or locally terminated DLCI
R4(config-subif)#frame-relay interface-dlci 403 ?
cisco Use CISCO Encapsulation
ietf Use RFC1490/RFC2427 Encapsulation
ppp Use RFC1973 Encapsulation to support PPP over FR protocol Optional protocol information for remote end
<cr>

R4#show frame-relay map -
Serial1/2.403 (up): point-to-point dlci, dlci 403(0xC9,0x3090), broadcast status defined, active
R4#

choices.B: remote DLCI on the main interface
choices.D: local DLCI on the main interface A

questions.answer_description: Interface fa0/0 breaks into sub interface and Main_Campus router is connected with switch via fa0/0. Subinterfaces configured with different subnet mask so its seem switch has multiple vlans and allow communication between vlan, router and inter-vlan we need to make a trunk port. So B will be the correct answer.

discussion.content:
B is the correct answer according to CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 Official Certification Guide.
“In addition, most Cisco routers do not attempt to negotiate trunking, so in most cases, both the router and switch need to manually configure trunking".
So, we have to think a lot on the exam.

The answer should be A.

You configure the trunk port on the switch not the router when configuring subinterfaces.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. What information about the interfaces on the Main_Campus router is true?
//IMG//

choices.D: The router is a modular router with five FastEthernet interfaces.
choices.A: The LAN interfaces are configured on different subnets.
choices.C: The Layer 2 protocol of interface Serial 0/1 is NOT operational.
choices.B: Interface FastEthernet 0/0 is configured as a trunk.

discussion.content:
Correct. The answer is B. I tested on real equipment as packet tracer can differ sometimes and I found that if you traceroute to an address not on any of those interfaces, you get a routing loop:

Router#traceroute 8.8.8.8 

Type escape sequence to abort.
Tracing the route to 8.8.8.8

1 172.16.100.1 0 msec 0 msec 0 msec
2 172.16.100.2 4 msec 0 msec 0 msec
3 172.16.100.1 4 msec 0 msec 0 msec
4 172.16.100.2 4 msec 0 msec 4 msec 
5 172.16.100.1 4 msec 0 msec 4 msec
<snip>
30 172.16.100.2 4 msec 4 msec 8 msec
Valid Answer is B. Router R2 will obtain a full routing table, including a default route, from R1. ciscoexam.online
There is no problem with neighbors . I tested in EVE-NG. I think it is no valid question.

On Packet Tracer, the output for R1 is:

R1#show ip route

Gateway of last resort is 0.0.0.0 to network 0.0.0.0

 172.16.0.0/16 is variably subnetted, 8 subnets, 5 masks
O 172.16.0.0/20 [110/65] via 172.16.100.2, 00:00:55, Serial0/0/0
O 172.16.16.0/20 [110/65] via 172.16.100.2, 00:00:45, Serial0/0/0
C 172.16.100.0/30 is directly connected, Serial0/0/0
L 172.16.100.1/32 is directly connected, Serial0/0/0
C 172.16.100.64/26 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/0
L 172.16.100.65/32 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/0
C 172.16.100.128/27 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/1
L 172.16.100.129/32 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/1
S* 0.0.0.0/0 is directly connected, Serial0/0/0

On Packet Tracer, the output is:

R2# show ip route

Gateway of last resort is 172.16.100.1 to network 0.0.0.0

 172.16.0.0/16 is variably subnetted, 8 subnets, 5 masks
C 172.16.0.0/20 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/0
L 172.16.0.1/32 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/0
C 172.16.16.0/20 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/1
L 172.16.16.1/32 is directly connected, GigabitEthernet0/1
C 172.16.100.0/30 is directly connected, Serial0/0/0
L 172.16.100.2/32 is directly connected, Serial0/0/0
O 172.16.100.64/26 [110/65] via 172.16.100.1, 00:00:28, Serial0/0/0
O 172.16.100.128/27 [110/65] via 172.16.100.1, 00:00:18, Serial0/0/0
O*E2 0.0.0.0/0 [110/1] via 172.16.100.1, 00:36:58, Serial0/0/0
I tested on Packet Tracer, and the answer is B.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. Assume that all of the router interfaces are operational and configured correctly. How will router R2 be affected by the configuration of R1 that is shown in the exhibit?
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
"ip route 0.0.0.0 0.0.0.0 serial0/0" is causing a loop. configuration is going to cause a loop and the link between R1 and R2 will be congested, OSPF will not perform relationship between them.
From its name, OSPF is a Link-State routing protocol, and the link state between R1 and R2 is simply down or something like that.

choices.D: R2 will not have a route for the directly connected serial network, but all other directly connected networks will be present, as well as the two Ethernet networks connected to R1.
choices.B: Router R2 will obtain a full routing table, including a default route, from R1.
choices.C: R2 will obtain OSPF updates from R1, but will not obtain a default route from R1.
choices.A: Router R2 will not form a neighbor relationship with R1.

discussion.content:
The answer should be D (late collisions).

Explanation: on page 283 of the book CCENT/CCNA ICND1 100-105 by Wendell Odom (printed May 2016)

Late Collisions: The subset of all collisions that happen after the 64th byte of the frame
has been transmitted. (In a properly working Ethernet LAN, collisions should occur within the first 64 bytes; late collisions today often point to a duplex mismatch.)

comments.content: I think answer should be both B and D. CRC reflects the input errors (section 8.2.4.3 connecting networks v6 companion guide by Cisco press)

questions.question_text: Which interface counter can you use to diagnose a duplex mismatch problem?

comments.content: i think that this entry doesnt appear cuz is the default hello interval

discussion.content: You could also put the same command on R2 to set the hello interval to 25 sec. But the answer is correct.

choices.D: Enable OSPF for R1 ethernet0/l; configure ip ospf 1 area 0 command under ethernet0/1.
choices.C: R2 ethernet0/1 and R3 ethernet0/0 are configured with a non-default OSPF hello interval of 25; configure no ip ospf hello-interval 25.
choices.B: R1 ethernet0/l configured with a non-default OSPF hello interval of 25; configure no ip ospf hello-interval 25.
choices.A: R1 ethernet0/1 is shutdown. Configure the no shutdown command.

questions.answer_description: Looking at the configuration of R1, we see that R1 is configured with a hello interval of 25 on interface Ethernet 0/1 while R2 is left with the default of 10 (not configured).
